content.body: No, if you use the plain `?` each is taken as a separate argument; you have to use the indexed variant to reuse placeholder args.
content.formatted_body: No, if you use the plain ? each is taken as a separate argument; you have to use the indexed variant to reuse placeholder args.

content.body: Since multiple placeholders is a more common case than reusing a single placeholder.

> <@tabatkins:matrix.org> Since multiple placeholders is a more common case than reusing a single placeholder.

So then you're undoing and redoing the meaningfulness of order in the same process ... interesting
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @tabatkins:matrix.org
Since multiple placeholders is a more common case than reusing a single placeholder.
So then you're undoing and redoing the meaningfulness of order in the same process ... interesting

content.body: I'm not sure what you mean - the placeholders are still subbed in order
But the whole point of PFA is order is meaningless. Otherwise, you can just use `.bind`
content.formatted_body: But the whole point of PFA is order is meaningless. Otherwise, you can just use .bind

content.body: One issue with `.bind` is there isn't a way to leave gaps
content.formatted_body: One issue with .bind is there isn't a way to leave gaps

content.body: Which is reordering, right? Leaving gaps means changing the argument order.
* having sudden flash backs to my  c++ days `std::bind(f, _1, 42, _2)`
content.formatted_body: • having sudden flash backs to my c++ days std::bind(f, _1, 42, _2)
